# Draft:Tina Edward Gunawardhana

Tina Edward Gunawardhana (born 30 July 1971) is a Britishâ€“Sri Lankan journalist, editor, entrepreneur, and community volunteer. She is the Deputy Editor of Hi!! Magazine, a Sri Lankan lifestyle publication, and a contributor to Life Online (Daily Mirror) and Ahasa, the inflight magazine of Mihin Air. She also works for British Airways and is the founder of the batik fashion brand Cherub. She has participated in community-led fundraising projects supporting under-resourced schools in Sri Lanka.
Early life and education
Gunawardhana was born in London, United Kingdom, on 30 July 1971. She moved to Sri Lanka in her early years to live with extended family and attended Methodist College, Colombo. In her late teens, she briefly studied journalism in Australia before returning to the UK.
Career
Journalism
Gunawardhana is the Deputy Editor of Hi!! Magazine in Sri Lanka and contributes to Life Online, the lifestyle section of the Daily Mirror (Sri Lanka). Her articles focus on travel, fashion, hospitality, and cultural commentary. She has also written for Ahasa, the inflight magazine of Mihin Air.
In December 2023, she was featured in an article by Metro UK about her decision to pass her maiden surname to her son.
Other professional work
Gunawardhana has held previous roles at Thames Water and Hodge Jones & Allen Solicitors. She currently works at British Airways while maintaining her career in journalism.
Fashion entrepreneurship
Gunawardhana is the founder of Cherub, a clothing brand that specializes in batik textiles. The brand operates in both the UK and Sri Lanka and features hand-dyed garments using traditional Sri Lankan methods.
Community involvement
Gunawardhana co-founded an informal initiative called Children of Lanka with a group of friends in the UK. Although not a registered charity, the group raised money through stalls at Sri Lankan community events and donated school supplies and essentials to rural schools in Sri Lanka.
Personal life
Gunawardhana is married and has one son. In a public interview, she explained her decision to give her son her own surname, Edward, citing cultural and practical reasons.
Selected works
* Contributor to Hi!! Magazine
* Contributor to Life Online (Daily Mirror)
* Articles for Ahasa inflight magazine
